Problem:
Consider a signal processing system where a signal \( x(t) \) undergoes a Fourier transform to produce \( X(f) \), which is then altered by a transfer function \( H(f) \) and subsequently inverse Fourier transformed to generate \( y(t) \).

If during the transformation process an additional filter \( G(f) \) is applied to \( X(f) \) after \( H(f) \) and before inverse transformation, will \( y(t) \) at the conclusion of this augmented process solely reflect the initial effect of \( H(f) \)?
Explanation: The additional application of \( G(f) \) as an intervention fundamentally alters \( Y(f) \) (the product of \( X(f) \) with \( H(f) \) and \( G(f) \)), complicating the resulting \( y(t) \). The final output is influenced by both \( H(f) \) and \( G(f) \), not just \( H(f) \).
